subject: argument parser: use CLI11 and add unit tests
commitMessage:
argument parser: use CLI11 and add unit tests

CLI11 is one of the most commonly use argument parser in OpenBMC. It can
save ~150 lines of codes in this project.

We are hitting argument related bugs that not covered in unit tests.
This test adds a test for argument parsing.

Tested: QEMU IPMI/Redfish worked.

Signed-off-by: Nan Zhou <nanzhoumails@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ib409c7e6a82ad31049f2da3e32727ebdf185f0fc

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 7047be6784455faa71f16ebbc66a74040634e350

This looks like a new feature that snuck into this commit.  In general, please try to put new features into a commit later than refactoring, unless there's a good reason to not.  As written, this adds dry-run, but I can't imagine why this would be required in the application, and your commit message doesn't answer that.  Was it just for testing?  If so, I suspect that a unit test for this would be much more useful than a dry run parameter.
This is not another new feature. The commit adds a bash script to test arguments and we need a way to not run the event loop. I mentioned this in the commit message now.
Please cover this in a conventional unit test, not a bash script.
This is essentially reinventing a bash unit test.  We should do this within the application unit tests in the more conventional (gtest) way.
Why can't we use this to test arguments? It's simple and effective. It gets the main function tested in a simple way.
Also, I don't want to reinvent a bash unit test if I have some existing Bash Unit Test framework to use (Google internal codes have this framework).

1st, We should be unit testing an application in the same language we code it in.  This is to ensure that maintainers of that application can maintain it.  We don't need a bash unit test framework at all, when the project  already has a unit test framework present.  The only real difference would be that it would require us abstract out the unit test parser into a testable unit, which we should do anyway.

2nd, we shouldn't be adding a new argument just to support unit testing on an argument parser.  If we did this for all unit tests in this application, it would get unmaintainable in a hurry.

I actually see a lot of bash unit tests in side Google. But I changed to C++ test here. Unit test mainapp is still missing if we don't have a way to stop running the event loop. 

PTAL.
Is it OK to drop this license in this case since we completely change the code? Or should I just keep it?
These license headers have never been enforcing, and IMO are a bit of an anti-pattern these days (not even the kernel has them anymore).  It should be fine to drop it.
Considering this returns void, why not just return Arguments rather than having an in-out parameter?
we exit.... then throw?  something seems odd with this line of code?

This is basically what CLI11_PARSE does. https://github.com/CLIUtils/CLI11/blob/e29cb3f1b47a973094813ef82c6e2dab84984336/include/CLI/App.hpp#L38

I changed to return integer just like main.

These now just throw, but the overall code flow doesn't catch these exceptions nor exit the process properly, so this code will just terminate on bad input with an uncaught exception.  Throwing through main is contrary to the coding standard (ie cppcoreguidelines).

The old behavior was more correct in this case.

FWIW, if we had clang-tidy running on this repo, it would've flagged this under the bugprone-exception-escape test.

https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/bugprone-exception-escape.html
Done. I changed to return integers and exit in main on failures. PTAL
Looking good except for the service file thing.
This is needed since I didn't find a good way in CLI11 to pass an empty string for UNIT. This is required to get Robot Test CI pass.

I'm not understanding this comment, and having to launch sh before launching the application is a level of complexity we  don't really want here.  When would we ever pass an empty string to this?

Even if we needed to, would quoting it (ie --unit="${UNIT}" ) solve the issue?  I'm still not sure why we need it though.

The problem comes from the "pcm@nslcd" service. I couldn't find the source of its env file. But in the QEMU, it's something like

```
ENDPOINT=nslcd
CERTPATH=/etc/ssl/certs/authority
TYPE=nslcd
```
which doesn't define "UNIT". It results in ExecStart is equal to "/usr/bin/env phosphor-certificate-manager --endpoint=xxx --path=xxx --unit= --type=xxx", and CLI11 complains about no TEXT for the unit option. 

I have tried various method

1. --unit="${UNIT}"
2. --unit='${UNIT}'
3. escape quote
4. escape single quote
5. default variable: ${UNIT:=""} and its escaped version

Unfortunately none of them worked. The reason might be cause by the weird systemd built-in string parse. "if else" with bash script is only one which worked. 

I also tried if there's a way to not requiring a value for an option in CLI11 but it seems impossible.

"/bin/sh" should be available in most linux distro. Given that many other OpenBMC and Google BMC services also use it, it might not be a big deal.
Can we just add UNIT to the PCM service file?

> actually... what even is pcm?
`phosphor-certificate-manager@nslcd.service`

Adding UNIT might work given that EnvironmentFile overrides Environment. I am testing the following on QEMU.

```
Environment=UNIT=""
EnvironmentFile=/usr/share/phosphor-certificate-manager/%I
ExecStart=/usr/bin/env phosphor-certificate-manager --endpoint ${ENDPOINT} --path ${CERTPATH} --type ${TYPE} --unit ${UNIT}
```
Done. Cool. It worked. And it's cleaner.

Just setting UNIT to empty string solves the problem?  Doesn't that just cause entity-manager to not accept this parameter at all?  I suspect there's something else going on here.  Won't this set every single Unit input arg to ""?  What about the services that need something non-empty string?

> Doesn't that just cause entity-manager to not accept this parameter at all?
Apologize, why is entity-manager related? This unit is just passed as a string to the daemon. The daemon will reload that unit if non-empty.

> Won't this set every single Unit input arg to ""?  What about the services that need something non-empty string?
Please see the environment configs https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/blob/master/dist/env/authority.
If Unit is set in "EnvironmentFile", it will override "Environment". I already tested the authority and nslcd daemon. Both worked.

Sorry, not entity-manager.  phosphor-certificate-manager.

> If Unit is set in "EnvironmentFile", it will override "Environment". I already tested the authority and nslcd daemon. Both worked.

ACK
Should we be printing the help strings here?  or does cli11 do that for us?
CLI does that when it calls app.exit() which is hidden in the CLI11_PARSE macro.

Looks reasonable.
 
Is there a recipe change that depends on CLI11?
No, will do after this gets a +2.
Please put that change in review now, please don't wait for +2 to put the patchset up.

probably should move the definition of enum CertificateType to an helper/utils file that way we need not include certificate.hpp here.

suggestion for your further cleanup.
Ack. Sure. added to my todo list, previously we are also talking about refactor and split the manager into separate source files.

Yeah, please see the other thread between Ed and me.


The problem comes from the "pcm@nslcd" service. I couldn't find the source of its env file. But in the QEMU, it's something like

```
ENDPOINT=nslcd
CERTPATH=/etc/ssl/certs/authority
TYPE=nslcd
```

which doesn't define "UNIT". It results in ExecStart is equal to "/usr/bin/env phosphor-certificate-manager --endpoint=xxx --path=xxx --unit= --type=xxx", and CLI11 complains about no TEXT for the unit option.
Will wait for one more day. No big change from the last +2, just conflict fixing.
